moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3
comment:
Obvious as this move seems,
it has not received any analytical attention, and we believe that this is the
first occasion of it having been introduced into practice in an important
match game. White must recover the pawn he now offers, and the position
afterwards is about even; but Blackburne and Zukertort are of the opinion that
the retention of the two bishops gives the second player the superior game,
though his pawns on the queenside are separated.

1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3
comment:
White could not well
venture upon taking the d-pawn, for it would have involved the loss of the
exchange, e.g.: 21.Rxd4 Rce8 22.Ra4 Bxe5 23.Rxe4 fxe4 24.Bxe5+ Kg8, and ought
to win.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6
comment:
The initiation of a
finely conceived scheme, altogether overlooked by the adversary.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2
comment:
White ought on the previous move to have played 25.Kf1, which would have
frustrated this neat design. As it stands, if White take the bishop with the
rook, Black would answer 26...Rxe1+, etc.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7
comment:
Fortunately for Steinitz, his opponent was at this point short of time, or
else the latter could not have failed to see that he could win the exchange by
27...Be5, threatening 28...g3. White had then no better reply than 28.Rxd4,
and he would have had very hard work afterwards to draw the game, even if he
found time to strengthen his position by pawn to g3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7 28. Ra6 Rc7 29. Kf1 Rd7 30. Ra3

1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7 28. Ra6 Rc7 29. Kf1 Rd7 30. Ra3 Ke6 31. Nd3 Bf8 32. Ra5
comment:
Preventing e
adversary's king from crossing, and better than checking at a6, which would
only have had the effect of drawing the king up to the support of his passed
d-pawn; for Black could have safely answered 32...Kd5, followed by 33...Ke4 if
the knight checked at f4, and White would then have found it of no avail to
protect the knight by 34.Bg3, threatening mate with the rook, since Black
could provide an escape by 34...d3, which also cleared the road to his own
victory.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7 28. Ra6 Rc7 29. Kf1 Rd7 30. Ra3 Ke6 31. Nd3 Bf8 32. Ra5 Bc2 33. Ke2 Kf6
comment:
Black played this with the anticipation that
White would answer 34.Kd2, whereupon he would capture the knight, followed by
35...Kg6, which would have given him a good game.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7 28. Ra6 Rc7 29. Kf1 Rd7 30. Ra3 Ke6 31. Nd3 Bf8 32. Ra5 Bc2 33. Ke2 Kf6 34. Ra6+
comment:
White failed here
to take the promptest advantage of the opponent's error. He might have taken
the a-pawn with the rook at once, but still the move adopted, drove the king
back, forced the gain of a pawn, and secured at least a draw.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5 Nf6 6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bg7 8. d4 O-O 9. Bxf4 Nxd5 10. Bxd5 Qxd5 11. O-O c5 12. Nc3 Qxd4+ 13. Qxd4 cxd4 14. Nd5 Nc6 15. Nxc6 bxc6 16. Ne7+ Kh8 17. Nxc6 Bb7 18. Ne5 Rac8 19. Rf2 Be4 20. Rd1 f5 21. Nd3 Rfe8 22. Re2 Kg8 23. Ne1 Kf7 24. Bg3 Re6 25. Bf2 Bxc2 26. Rxe6 Bxd1 27. Rd6 Ke7 28. Ra6 Rc7 29. Kf1 Rd7 30. Ra3 Ke6 31. Nd3 Bf8 32. Ra5 Bc2 33. Ke2 Kf6 34. Ra6+ Kg7
comment:
A grave error, for it loses two pawns at once. He ought to have 34...Ke7; but
even in that case his game was not comfortable, and he must have lost the
a-pawn by the answer of 35.Nc5, without being able to make any impression with
his passed d-pawn, which could easily be stopped.

comment: And after some more moves Black resigned. Duration 7 hours. (...)
